title: A Survey on Reinforcement Learning Security with Application to Autonomous Driving
abstract:
Reinforcement learning allows machines to learn from their own experience.
Nowadays, it is used in safety-critical applications, such as autonomous
driving, despite being vulnerable to attacks carefully crafted to either
prevent that the reinforcement learning algorithm learns an effective and
reliable policy, or to induce the trained agent to make a wrong decision. The
literature about the security of reinforcement learning is rapidly growing, and
some surveys have been proposed to shed light on this field. However, their
categorizations are insufficient for choosing an appropriate defense given the
kind of system at hand. In our survey, we do not only overcome this limitation
by considering a different perspective, but we also discuss the applicability
of state-of-the-art attacks and defenses when reinforcement learning algorithms
are used in the context of autonomous driving.

Reinforcement learning allows machines to learn from their own experience. Nowadays, it is used in safety-critical applications,
such as autonomous driving, despite being vulnerable to attacks carefully crafted to either prevent that the reinforcement learning
algorithm learns an effective and reliable policy, or to induce the trained agent to make a wrong decision. The literature about the
security of reinforcement learning is rapidly growing, and some surveys have been proposed to shed light on this field. However, their
categorizations are insufficient for choosing an appropriate defense given the kind of system at hand. In our survey, we do not only
overcome this limitation by considering a different perspective, but we also discuss the applicability of state-of-the-art attacks and
defenses when reinforcement learning algorithms are used in the context of autonomous driving.

INTRODUCTION
Reinforcement learning (RL) is a process that teaches machines to perform a task using a reward-based learning system,
which is a technique also exploited by the human brain [17]. The machine tries to perform an action, and if it gets a
positive (negative) reward/outcome, it will be more (less) likely to repeat that action in the future.
For its ability to solve complex, dynamic, and high-dimensional problems [60], RL is used in many applications.
Notably, it is used even in the high-risk, high-value ones such as cybersecurity [60] and autonomous driving [41]. The
first use RL to detect and fight against sophisticated cyberattacks such as falsified data injection in cyber-physical
systems [98], intrusion to host computers or networks [51] and malware [91]. While the latter makes extensive use of

RL to accomplish different tasks such as path planning and the development of high-level driving policies for complex
navigation tasks [41].
Unfortunately, RL is vulnerable to different types of attacks [36] that can alter the agents‚Äô behavior. For example,
an autonomous driving car that uses RL to establish its driving policies can be induced to cause a car crash or traffic
jam. As RL is frequently applied in mission-critical tasks like those mentioned above, its security is of great concern,
and the literature about this topic is rapidly proliferating. Different surveys [4, 14, 36] have been published on this
topic. However, most of them [4, 14] only consider earlier, pioneering works, while the most recent taxonomy provided
in [36] does not allow system designers to understand which defenses can be applied to protect a given RL model (based
on its characteristics) against a particular attack. Our survey aims to overcome this shortcoming. The first contribution
provided by our survey is a categorization that allows system designers to understand which defense they can apply
to defend the system at hand against a precise threat. The second is to categorize all the literature about attacks and
defenses against RL (more than 50 papers) accordingly. Our third contribution is to examine to which extent the attacks
and defenses proposed against RL can be applied to the autonomous-driving systems, motivated by the fact that the
latter is a safety-critical application. Finally, we explain that attacks and defenses against RL are strongly inspired
by those devised many years ago against machine-learning classifiers [7]. However, RL has peculiarities that make
the application of these attacks not straightforward. For this reason, only a subset of the attacks previously proposed
against classifiers has been tested against RL. This parallel allows us to provide our fourth contribution: a discussion
about open challenges and interesting research directions about the security of RL.
We start our review in Sect. 2, providing the reader with the background about reinforcement learning essential
to understanding how those algorithms work and, consequently, how they can be threatened. For the same reason,
in Sect. 3, we highlight the peculiarities of reinforcement learning algorithms used for autonomous driving. Then,
in Sect. 4 we present a threat model that encompasses all literature about the security of reinforcement learning. In
Sect. 5 (6), we explain how attacks (defenses) can be categorized, and we present a taxonomy of the state-of-the-art
attacks (defenses). In this sections, we review all the works about the security of reinforcement learning, discuss their
applicability to systems developed for autonomous driving, and highlight future research directions.
To summarize, with this work, we provide the following contributions:
‚Ä¢ we propose a categorization of attacks and defenses that allows matching, for the RL system at hand, specific
attacks with appropriate defenses;
‚Ä¢ we categorize more than 50 papers about the security of reinforcement learning;
‚Ä¢ we discuss the applicability of state-of-art attacks and defenses to RL algorithms in the context of autonomous
driving;
‚Ä¢ comparing work on the security of RL with that of ML systems, to which the first is highly inspired, we highlight
open challenges and interesting research directions.
2
REINFORCEMENT LEARNING
Reinforcement learning is a methodology that allows learning from experience. This mechanism is unconsciously used
every day by our brain. Humans perform actions, and if they get a positive outcome, they will repeat them in the future,
expecting to receive the favorable outcome again. In contrast, if these actions have an unpleasant outcome, they are
less likely to repeat them to avoid receiving that outcome again [17].

This technique has been successfully used also to teach machines to perform complex tasks in dynamic environments.
For example, it is used to train autonomous driving cars to drive through traffic [41], which is a highly challenging
problem. While learning to drive, there are, in fact, many challenges to face, such as predicting and taking into account
the behavior of the other cars, even when they are violating some rules, e.g., passing despite the red light.
In this section, we provide the reader with the background about RL. First, we describe the components of the RL
system. Then, we explain how state-of-the-art systems can be categorized.
2.1
Components of Reinforcement Learning Systems
In the following, we will describe the RL system components and explain how they interplay. The reader can find them
illustrated in Figure 1. While describing them, we also start presenting the notation that we will use in this survey,
which is summarized in Table 1.
Agent. An agent is an entity that lives in and influences the considered scenario. For example, if we consider the
application of autonomous driving, each car driving on the street and each pedestrian walking on it will be an agent.
The agent we aim to teach something using RL techniques is usually called the ego agent.
Action. An action ùëéis a move an agent can make in the considered scenario. When the time in which the agent
performs the action is relevant, we will denote the action performed at time ùë°as ùëéùë°. This action can be chosen between
a set of all possible actions the attacker can make. For example, turn right, turn left, accelerate, decelerate, and keep
going without making any changes. The set of possible actions is usually named the Action Space, and denoted as A.
Environment. The environment E is the considered scenario and thus the place where the agents live; e.g., the street
where cars and pedestrians move on. Besides the agents, the environment can contain other elements relevant to the
ego agent; e.g., street signals and traffic lights.
State. The state s is a collection of values that encode the environment‚Äôs conditions. For example, the position of the
agents in it, the color of the traffic lights, etc. The agents‚Äô actions usually alter the environment state. For example,
when a car turns right, its position will change (and thus the environment state which includes it). We denote as sùë°+1
the state in which the environment is induced when the agent performs the action ùëéùë°.

the environment. For example, the ego car would receive a positive reward if an action reduces the distance from

performed at time ùë°, the ego agent will receive the reward denoted with ùëüùë°.

2.2
Solving the Reinforcement Learning Problem
The problem of teaching the agent to accomplish a task can thus be formulated as the problem of finding the optimal
policy. The general formulation treats the problem as a Markov decision process (MDP). An MDP is a reinforcement

Approximations. For finite MDPs, the Bellman optimality equation can be solved by defining a system of equations
with one equation for each state. For non-finite MDPs, however, this solution makes assumptions that are not always
possible in real cases. The assumptions that are often difficult to satisfy are: (i) the environment is perfectly known in
its dynamics; (ii) the problem can be solved with the available computational resources; and (iii) the problem satisfies
the Markov property. Among these three assumptions, the second one is the most problematic. In real scenarios, indeed,
the number of states might be intractable (or infinite). For example, the number of states in the game of Backgammon is
about 1020, and in autonomous driving it is usually infinite. This makes the MDP problem computationally unsolvable.
Typically, in these cases, the problem is simplified with approximations that reduce the search space [83]. MDPs are
thus usually solved with different learning algorithms that approximate the value and the Q-functions (by using linear
combinations of features, deep neural networks, or other functions) and attempt to generalize to unseen states (by
observing similarities from states seen in training). Other simplifications are given, for example, by setting an upper
bound to the maximum number of states, i.e., by limiting the number of RL steps for which the agent can perform its
actions. A taxonomy of these algorithms will be detailed in Section 2.3.
2.3
Categorization of Reinforcement Learning Systems
In this section, we explain how the state-of-the-art algorithms for reinforcement learning can be categorized depending
on their features, and we discuss exemplary approaches of each category.
Single-Agent versus Multi-Agent RL. Depending on the number of agents whose actions influence the environment,
RL is denoted as single-agent if a single agent alters the environment, i.e., it can change its state, and multi-agent if
multiple agents influence the environment. Multi-agent systems are thus far more complex, as the behavior of many
different agents alters the environment and thus has an influence on the ego agent. An example in which the ego car
should be modeled within other cars on the road is the problem of modeling stop-and-go behavior during potential
traffic jams [94].
Model-based versus Model-free RL. The environment of an RL agent can be explicitly modeled or implicitly
learned [39]. RL is considered as model-based if it creates a model of the environment, which in the following we will
denote as M, and model-free otherwise. Model-based RL learns to predict the reward and the next state and bases its
decisions on these predictions. Model-free RL, instead, does not try to model the environment, as it bases its decisions
only on the information obtained by interacting with the environment. For example, tabular certainty-equivalence
(TCE) [54] models the environment as a Markov decision process or as a graph with associated actions, transition proba-
bilities, and rewards. TCE is thus a model-based RL approach, where the policy is derived from this environment model.
On the other hand, most recent works, including deep-learning-based RL such as deep Q-networks (DQN) [57, 103]
or proximal policy optimization (PPO) [28, 77] are model-free: they do not estimate explicit transition probabilities
of the environment. Instead, they often model only the options available from the current state without modeling
future possibilities in detail. The transitions are thus implicitly estimated, as opposed to explicitly modeled as in TCE,
for example. In this sense, model-based approaches have the advantage of allowing the agent to think ahead or plan.
However, this comes at the price of larger sample complexity, as building a model is costly in terms of the need for data
about the environment. Modeling the environment can also present a challenge when this model diverges from the
real environment. This is a particularly relevant problem in autonomous driving, as traffic might be too complex to be
explicitly modeled. Consequently, most works considered in this survey are model-free approaches.
Policy Updates. When learning a policy, the agent interacts with the environment with a given frequency. Depending
on the frequency with which the policy is updated, RL is referred to as: (1) on-policy RL, when the policy is updated after
6
A Survey on Reinforcement Learning Security
Woodstock ‚Äô18, June 03‚Äì05, 2018, Woodstock, NY
each interaction with the environment; (2) off-policy RL, when the policy is updated sporadically, i.e., after different
iterations with the environment; and (3) offline RL, when the agent is just presented with collected data without being
able to interact with the environment [68]. For example, PPO [28, 77] is on-policy, and the learned policy is directly
applied to the environment and used to take actions and thus sample further data from the environment. In contrast,
DQN [57, 103] is an off-policy approach. Here, the policy can also be updated using data from previous policies, which
were different from the current policy. In this sense, all the interactions seen are saved and can be used for learning,
leading to offline learning. Almost all algorithms considered in this survey are either on- or off-policy, except the
planning-based offline agent studied by Rakhsha et al. [72]. Due to the lack of evaluation benchmarks, offline RL is, in
fact, the least used, although it is considered promising as it allows to take advantage of large, existing datasets [25].
3
REINFORCEMENT LEARNING FOR AUTONOMOUS DRIVING
One possible application area for RL is autonomous driving. This setting favors certain RL systems, whereas other
previously-discussed properties map to specific implementations of autonomous driving. In this section, we discuss
these relations in detail. In the first subsection, we set the previously introduced categorization of RL in relation to
autonomous driving tasks. In the second subsection, we discuss the components of an autonomous car to understand
how RL is applied and how RL potentially interacts with additional components within the car.
3.1
Driving Automation and Reinforcement Learning Approaches
In the previous section, we categorized RL along single-agent or multi-agent systems, the kind of modelling, and the
way the policy is updated. To understand how these categorizations relate to autonomous driving tasks, we first need
to understand how cars are automated. To this end, we review the six levels of automation in driving as defined by the
Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE) [75]. We will start with the lowest level and progress towards more autonomy.
Level 0. No automation, but automatic systems may provide warnings or momentary assistance. Examples are
lane departure warnings or emergency braking systems.
Level 1. The driver monitors the environment and controls the car, but the system supports the driver by either
breaking or accelerating. Examples include lane-centering or cruise control.
Level 2. The driver monitors the environment and controls the car, but the system supports the driver by
breaking and accelerating. Examples include lane centering and simultaneous cruise control.
Level 3. The system controls the car, but the driver may be requested to take over control at any time. Examples
include a traffic jam chauffeur.
Level 4. The system controls the car without any intervention by a human, but it can drive only in particular
areas. Examples include a driverless taxi restricted to a small geographic area, such as an airport).
Level 5. The system controls the car without any intervention by a human.
When applying RL, these levels, for example, determine whether the required RL system can be considered single agent
(levels 1-4) or has to be multi-agent (levels 4 and 5). More concretely, at low automation levels, the agent is tailored
for specific tasks (for example, lane keeping), that do not involve interacting with other vehicles. As the driver is still
responsible for controlling the car, the agent can focus on its specific task. When the agent instead fully controls the
car, interactions with other agents (like, for example, other vehicles or pedestrians) are unavoidable.
Concerning the model-free and model-based distinction, we have to consider the enormous complexity of the
environment, in particular at higher automation levels (level > 3). The more complex the environment is, the harder

avoids potentially dangerous situations, as otherwise, a sub-optimal policy may be used and take actions that are not
safe. However, there is still the possibility to train on- or off-policy, but in a virtual environment. In terms of deployed
autonomous cars, there might be the possibility that off-policy allows the deployment of a sufficiently mature policy
regularly updated by the vendor, as already established by car vendors nowadays.1
3.2
Autonomous Driving Components and the Application of Reinforcement Learning
The RL agent should not be seen in isolation from the vehicle it controls: to allow full (or also partial) automation,
different types of sensors and components are required. Previous works describe these components at different levels
of abstraction [20, 26, 69]. We chose the three-level abstraction structure by Pendleton et al. [66], which divides the
information flow through the car. More specifically, the information is first perceived (perception), then used to derive
actions (planning) which are then carried out (control). We now review each of these steps with a focus on reinforcement
learning. We illustrate the main components of the abstraction in Figure 2.
Perception. As a first step, the car must be capable of perceiving its environment as a basis for any future decision or
output. This may include the localization of the car but mainly relates to the perception of the environment, generally
based on sensors. We now give an overview of the commonly used sensors, inspired by Dede et al. [27]. One example is
the LiDAR sensor, with a range of up to 200 meters for collision avoidance. A sensor similar to LiDAR is Radar with a
similar range, yet it may also be used for collision detection in the closer vicinity of the vehicle. Both inputs can be
represented, for example, as point clouds. Other sensors include cameras for object detection, which typically cover
a range of up to 100 meters and yield images or videos. Ultrasonic sensors have a short range and are often used for
1See, for example, https://www.tesla.com/support/software-updates.
8
A Survey on Reinforcement Learning Security
Woodstock ‚Äô18, June 03‚Äì05, 2018, Woodstock, NY
parking assistance. Several sensors are often used in conjunction for redundancy and thus increase the reliability of
collected inputs. In addition to mere sensing, this layer may incorporate tasks such as object detection, depth estimation,
and semantic segmentation, where inputs are already processed, resulting in aggregated information. These parts are
vulnerable to specific attacks as well [13, 96], but for the sake of this survey, we will focus on attacks targeting the RL
component specifically.
Planning. Receiving the previously-collected inputs and, potentially, inputs from other vehicles, an RL agent can
be trained to solve different tasks, including, for example, path planning. In the following sections, we will discuss
tasks such as deriving steering output prediction from input images [8, 81, 95, 99], traffic simulation [94], and path
finding [54]. Depending on the task, the requirements of an RL agent may vary greatly. An agent can maneuver a car
on a highway, where different non-autonomous vehicles are present. In this case, the RL system must be guaranteed to
operate in real-time. However, small delays may be more acceptable for a vehicle operating in an area void of humans
(both pedestrians and drivers). Along these lines, it is crucial whether the system is multi-agent (e.g., is aware of other
reactive agents in its environment) or whether it considers the environment as static. The latter limits a system to an
artificial setting where no interaction with other vehicles or pedestrians takes place. The multi-agent setting can be
considered the bare minimum for maneuvering realistic traffic situations.
Control. Once target actions have been identified, the vehicle needs to act upon these. This step involves communication
with the actuators and path and trajectory tracking or keeping track that indented actions are carried out as previously
planned. While there are potentially applicable mathematical modeling tools, machine learning, and RL systems used in
this step, there is no previous work dealing with the RL security of this component, at least to the best of our knowledge.
The security of control systems in general, however, is subject to ongoing research [5].
Further Components. There are parts of the autonomous car that we skipped previously for simplicity. For example,
the application of sensors requires software. To ensure communication between individual components, each car
contains different CAN buses. Similar layers to translate the output of the RL agent to the car are also required. Each of
these components may include a security vulnerability. As we will see in the next section, some attacks assume not to
alter the environment but the information provided to the RL agent [81, 90, 103].
4
THREAT MODEL
In this section, we describe a threat model that can be used to characterize attacks against RL. We characterize the
attack according to (1) the goal of the attacker, (2) the knowledge the attacker has about the target system, and (3) the
attacker‚Äôs capabilities of manipulating input data and/or tampering with the system components.
4.1
Goal
The attacker‚Äôs goal is the result they would like to obtain by perpetrating their attack. The goals can be broadly
categorized according to the security violation they cause. They can cause an integrity violation, e.g., to force the agent
to perform a particular action at a specific point in time without compromising normal system operations. For example,
it can force an agent that models an autonomous car to steer in the wrong direction in a curve. They can cause an
availability violation that compromises the system‚Äôs functionalities. For example, an attacker can alter a portion of the
training data, making the agent unable to learn to accomplish its task or learn to perform a task different from the one
for which it was devised. Finally, they can cause a privacy violation by obtaining private information about the system
or the data used to train it by reverse-engineering the learning algorithm.
9
Woodstock ‚Äô18, June 03‚Äì05, 2018, Woodstock, NY
Demontis, et al.
4.2
Knowledge
The attacker can have different levels of knowledge of the targeted system, including (i) the training data, (ii) the
observations, (iii) the RL algorithm, (iv) the learned policy, (v) the actions performed by the agent, and (vi) the reward.
If the attackers know everything about the system, the attack is named white-box. This setting is often unrealistic
but allows system designers to perform a worst-case evaluation of the security of the RL policy at hand, providing
empirical upper bounds on the performance degradation that may incur under attack.
The attacker can have limited knowledge of the system; they might know only some of the components mentioned
above. For example, the attacker might know the observations and the reward obtained by the agent from the environ-
ment, but they might be unaware of the target RL algorithm. Attackers can also have full knowledge of the system, but
they might be able to acquire this knowledge only after a few seconds, i.e., when the system has already altered its
state. If the attacker has only a limited knowledge of the system, the attack is denoted as gray-box. To carry out attacks
in this scenario, attackers might exploit a property of the attacks called transferability [19]. Namely, they can create a
surrogate RL system, devise the attack against the surrogate and then employ the crafted attack against their target.
When the attacker does not have any knowledge about the RL system, the attack is named black-box.
4.3
Capabilities
Attackers might have different capabilities that they can leverage to achieve their goals. Firstly, they can have or do not
have the ability to alter training data. If the attacker alters the training data, the attack is defined as a training-time
(poisoning) attack. Otherwise, it is defined as a test-time attack. Moreover, they can have the ability to change (ùëê(ùë•)) or
monitor (ùëö(ùë•)) some input/output ùë•of the target system. In Figure 3, we highlight in red the components of the system
shown in Figure 1 that attackers can manipulate without having access to the RL algorithm. Attackers can directly
manipulate the environment, for example, by adding objects (such as the red box shown in Figure 3) to the scenario or
by employing agents that adopt a malicious policy. Attackers can also tamper with the sensors to alter the ego agent
observations. In this way, the agent will perform the best action for the perceived state, which would be different from
the actual state of the environment. Therefore, the agent will perform an action that is not optimal for the actual state
of the environment. Even if this might be less likely to happen, attackers may also alter the RL algorithm‚Äôs code used to
train the agent, as previously done in [56].
4.4
Usage of an Agent
When running attacks against reinforcement learning systems, attackers can also leverage an agent to achieve their
malicious goals. There are different ways in which this can happen, as detailed below.
‚Ä¢ As explained before, when the attackers do not have perfect knowledge about their target system, they can train
a surrogate model, which in the following we will denote with ‚âàM (i.e., a system which approximates the target
model).
‚Ä¢ In a multi-agent RL system, multiple agents influence the environment and thus its state, which is given as an
input to the ego agent. Therefore attackers can use an agent included in the environment (‚ààE) to carry out the
attack.
‚Ä¢ Attackers can also leverage an agent not included in the environment (‚àâE) to enhance their attack. For example,
they can use it to understand how to alter the environment to cause the misbehavior of their target agent.
In the following, we will use the symbol ‚àÖto denote the case where the attacker does not use any malicious agent.

5
ATTACKS
Despite the promising results reported in the literature, RL is vulnerable to different attacks. As we will explain later,
the attack strategies proposed against RL are a subset of those proposed against ML. In the following, we will first
explain how state-of-the-art attacks against RL can be categorized. Then, we will present a taxonomy of the attacks
proposed against Single-agent and Multi-agent reinforcement learning systems. We describe them separately as the
attacks potentially applicable to multi-agent RL systems are more complex. Indeed, in multi-agent RL, the attacker
can exploit other agents that impact the environment to mount the attack. For the article that considers autonomous
driving as their case study, we will provide further details about the supposition behind them and their applicability to
reality. Finally, we will discuss interesting feature directions regarding developing attacks against RL.
5.1
Categorizing the Attacks against RL
Our taxonomy aims to be helpful to both researchers and practitioners. Therefore, our categorization highlights the
relevant characteristics of the attacks and the systems to which they have been applied. This allows the readers to
understand which attacks are applicable to a chosen RL system and to notice blind spots, namely the RL system for
which no attacks have been devised yet.
We categorize the attacks against RL in terms of:
‚Ä¢ Policy Update. The frequency with which the policy is updated (on-policy, off-policy, offline). This is relevant
because, depending on this, training time attacks may or not have an immediate influence on the system;
‚Ä¢ Model-based. Their eventual ability to model the environment. It is true if the RL algorithm models the environment
and false otherwise. Systems that model the environment may be potentially attacked, also making the system
unable to learn to predict the environment outputs;
‚Ä¢ Attacker‚Äôs Capability. That denotes the capabilities the attackers have to have to perpetrate the attack. It is
subdivided in: (1) Attacker‚Äôs Action, which is the action that must be performed by the attacker, and, as we
discussed, could be to monitor the inputs of the RL system or to alter them (2) Poisoning the eventual ability of
the attackers to alter the input during training, which can be true if they have this capability and false otherwise.;

‚Ä¢ Attacker‚Äôs Knowledge. Level of knowledge of the victim system, which may be white-, gray-, and black-box;
‚Ä¢ Attacker‚Äôs goal. The result the attackers would like to obtain with their attack;

that will occur earlier than the state in which it would like to perpetrate the attack;

The possible attackers‚Äô goals depend on the type of system the attacker is targeting. In the following, we discuss
the attackers‚Äô goals considered by the works that proposed attacks against RL. In Table 2, we have categorized them
according to the security violation they cause, which can be integrity, availability, or privacy violation (see Sect. 4 for
further details) and the capability required for the attacker (if he should be able to change/monitor the training data or
only the test data). In the following, we first describe the attackers‚Äô goals that can be achieved by changing/monitoring
only the test data, then the ones for which it is necessary also to change/monitor the training data.
Test time attacks. The attacks that manipulate only the test data cause either integrity or privacy violations. The
attacks that cause the former can have two different goals:
‚Ä¢ They can make the environment reach a target state (reach(sùëá)); e.g., they can make a car turn in the wrong
direction in a curve, causing the collision with the guardrail;
‚Ä¢ They can force the agent to perform the action that minimizes the return (min(R)); e.g., in a two-player game,
the attacker can alter the input of the opponent to make it perform a silly action, increasing its likelihood to win
the game.
To perform these attacks, the attacker should have the capability to change (c) some test inputs. The attacks that cause
privacy violations proposed so far monitor (m) the agent‚Äôs behavior to clone its policy. This attack is called model
stealing (steal(M)) [62].
Training time attacks. To perform these attacks, the attacker should have the capability to change (c) some inputs
received by the reinforcement learning system at training time. The attacks that manipulate the training data proposed
so far can cause either an availability or an integrity violation. The attacks that cause an availability violation can have
as a goal:
12
A Survey on Reinforcement Learning Security
Woodstock ‚Äô18, June 03‚Äì05, 2018, Woodstock, NY
‚Ä¢ Forcing the agent to learn a target policy, namely a policy chosen by the attacker. For example, they can make
an artificial intelligence implementing an opponent in a two-player game learn to help the player instead of
impeding him. We denote them as (learn(ùúãùëá));
‚Ä¢ Make the agent unable to learn to accomplish its task correctly, minimizing the return (min(R)). For example,
they can make a car unable to learn to drive safely;
The attacks that cause an integrity violation:
‚Ä¢ Inject training data containing a particular pattern called ‚Äútrigger‚Äù to alter the agent‚Äôs agent behavior at test time
in the presence of the trigger. For example, the car can behave normally in the presence of known traffic signs
and adopt a strange behavior only when it encounters a stop sign with a yellow sticker (the trigger) attached.
The attacks exploiting such a mechanism are called Backdoor poisoning [29]. We denote them as (learn(ùúãùêµ)) as
the agent learns a policy that contains a backdoor, which makes the agent adopt a target policy but only in the
presence of a trigger. The attacker should be able to alter also the test data to add the trigger.
‚Ä¢ Force the agent to learn to employ a target policy, namely a policy chosen by the attacker only for a subset of
states. The agent will employ the optimal policy when receiving the other states. For example, they can make a
car learn to go astray only when crossing a yellow car. We define this attack as Targeted Poisoning and we denote
this goal as (learn(ùúãùëás )). The main difference with Backdoor Poisoning is that Backdoor Poisoning forces the
agent to misbehave in the presence of states defined by the attacker and then manipulates the environment to
contain the trigger at test time. In contrast, Targeted Poisoning makes the agent misbehave in the presence of
states that do not appear frequently but are not altered ad-hoc by the attacker. Thus the attacker does not need
the ability to manipulate the test samples but only the training samples.
Training time integrity attacks are hard to spot by observing the agent‚Äôs behavior, as it behaves as expected in most
cases. Its behavior is unusual only in the presence of the trigger (subset of states).
5.2
Attacks against Single-agent RL
In this section, we present the literature about attacks against single-agent RL systems in the following. First, in Table 3,
we provide a schematic overview. We then describe the attacks in more detail, subdividing them according to the
security violation they cause.
Integrity Violation. Integrity attacks make the system behave as expected by the attacker on particular inputs without
compromising the system behavior on legitimate, unmodified inputs.
As explained before, an attacker can cause an integrity violation by having the ability to modify only the test data.
In the following, we describe test-time integrity attacks. The majority of the proposed attacks alter a component
of the system (state, action, environment, or observations) to minimize the expected reward for a particular input
[33, 46, 56, 85, 95, 99, 100, 103]. The attacker often modifies a system component only slightly, by applying a perturbation
bounded with an Lp-norm constraint [48, 85, 100], making the attack difficult to be detected. To carry out these attacks,
the attacker often tampers with the sensors. Alternatively, the authors of [85] exploit adversarial patches [9], namely,
small stickers containing an evident perturbation. The advantage of adversarial patches is that they can be printed
and used to alter the environment; therefore, attackers can perpetrate this attack even if they do not have access to
the sensors. The authors of [85], considering a system trained to grasp objects based on visual input, show that the
agent can become unable to perform its task when the patch is present. They consider 100 object-grasping episodes and

makes the agent act randomly every time the trigger is present in the input. This attack is difficult to detect because the
agent‚Äôs behavior is sensible when the trigger is not present. The attack force the agent to assume the desired behavior
at test time only when an input containing the trigger is presented. In [1], the authors propose an attack similar to
[40] that makes the agent learn to perform a target policy when the trigger is present in the input. Interestingly, in
this paper, the authors propose the concept of in-distribution triggers. Namely, patterns that can occur due to agent
interaction with the environment and thus are difficult to detect when used as a trigger. The authors show that the
attack succeeds by adding 10-20% samples containing the trigger.
Availability Violation. As we explained before, availability attacks, also called denial-of-service attacks, make the
system unusable. The availability attacks proposed against RL modify a portion of the training data to make the agent
unable to learn to accomplish the task correctly. In [55], the authors propose a black-box attack. They assume the
attacker does not have any knowledge about the learned policy, but they can sometimes flip the sign of the reward
when the environment reaches a chosen state. Their work focuses on on-policy RL and analyzes different exploration
strategies. Their experimental analysis shows that small exploration probabilities are more resilient to perturbations of
the reward. In [35, 54, 72, 102], the authors alter the reward to force the agent to learn a policy chosen by the attacker,
e.g., make a robot learn to reach a location chosen by the attacker instead of the location desired by the developer of
the RL system.
Privacy Violation. So far, to the best of our knowledge, no attack has been proposed against single-agent RL algorithms.
As explained in the previous sections, the adaptation of attacks previously proposed against standard ML systems to RL
is not straightforward. Therefore many of the former have not been tested yet against RL.

5.3
Attacks against Multi-agent RL
In the following, we present the literature about attacks against multi-agent RL. Table 4 presents the taxonomy of the
state-of-the-art attacks against multi-agent RL, and then we describe them in more detail.
Integrity Violation. The majority of the proposed test-time attacks manipulate some system components to minimize
the expected reward [28, 37, 43, 44, 74, 81, 82, 86, 90]. In [86], the authors claim that test-time attacks against DRL, to
be practical, should work disregarding the current state of the system. The reason is that pre-computing an adversarial
example for each possible state is not feasible in practice, as the possible states are often too many, and the attacker
would not be able to compute the attack for the current state before the state is already changed. To solve this problem,
they consider universal adversarial examples [59] that can be computed offline and are effective for different states.
Only the work in [47] proposes test-time attacks that make the environment reach a particular state desired by the
attacker.
A few attacks alter the training data to make the agent perform an attacker-chosen action when a particular state
(trigger) occurs. In particular, they exploit other agents to trigger the desired behavior. The work in [93] considers
a competitive two-player RL system and uses the opponent‚Äôs behavior to trigger the backdoor. In [94], instead, the
authors consider a traffic congestion control system, and assume that the attacker uses the state of the car agents in the
neighborhood of the ego agent to trigger the backdoor.
Availability Violation. In [3], the authors propose a training time attack that causes an availability violation. With
ad-hoc manipulation of the environment at training time, the attack proposed in this work makes the RL learn a target
policy. The authors of the work in [28], instead considers a two-player game and exploits the behavior of an agent
within the environment (the opponent) to make the ego agent unable to win the match. This attack is named adversarial
policy.
Privacy Violation. So far, only the work in [12] proposes an attack that compromises the privacy of RL. In particular,
the authors of [12] propose a methodology to perform model stealing ad-hoc for DRL algorithms. This attack creates a
clone of a target RL policy. Many different attacks were previously proposed against deep learning, but they were not
applicable to DRL due to its complexity, stochasticity, and limited observable information. The attack proposed by the
authors is based on imitation learning, a well-established solution to learning sequential decision-making policies. The
desiderata for the copied model can be (1) accuracy, namely the ability to match or exceed the accuracy of the original
model; (2) fidelity, namely a similar behavior to the original model (even committing the same errors). The authors
showed the proposed attack achieves both high accuracy and fidelity.
5.4
Attacks on Autonomous Driving
In this section, we discuss attacks specifically in relation to autonomous driving. We first review attacks that specifically
target autonomous vehicles and discuss which properties are required for an attack to be a real-world threat. We
conclude this section by discussing future work.
State of the Art. We summarize attacks that have been evaluated in driving scenarios in Table 5. Two of these six
attacks are evaluated in a multi-agent context. Although a car that operates in a single-agent system is limited to an
autonomy level 4, and a multi-agent system approach is required for level 5, single-agent attacks may still work on
multi-agent capable cars. In this sense, cars with automation level 5 are, in principle vulnerable towards more kinds of
attacks. Of six attacks on autonomous driving tasks, four are evasion attacks, all on end-to-end systems, attempting
to make the vehicle leave the lane [8, 81, 99] or trigger suboptimal behavior [95], all potentially triggering a crash.

Although neither is evaluated on a real vehicle, Boloor et al. [8] considers an attacker that paints lines on the street and
Xiao et al. [95] with printed perturbations. Interestingly, in [8], autonomous driving is considered as a case study. The
attacker is assumed to manipulate the scenario, painting some black lines on the street, making the car agent turn in
the wrong direction. The authors show that their attack is effective using a driving simulator. Yang et al. [99] propose
instead to tamper with the sensor input altering them leveraging the system‚Äôs gradients with respect to the output.
Yet differently, Sun et al. [81] propose to alter the environment‚Äôs response to the agents behavior. Furthermore, Ma
et al. [54] introduces a policy-poisoning attack that affects the planning component in a toy example, resulting in the
car taking a sub-optimal route to the target. This is achieved by tampering with the rewards during the training of
the model. Finally, Wang et al. [94] introduces a backdoor attack, affecting the controller component of a connected
autonomous vehicle to cause a traffic jam or a crash, by considering two different desired behaviors: (1) acceleration
and deceleration to cause traffic congestion, (2) acceleration to cause a crash with the vehicle on the front. The authors
tested the effectiveness of the proposed attack using a simulator and both a single- and a two-lane circuit. However,
this methodology does not target the car itself but the algorithm controlling the cars to optimize traffic flow. The
authors embed a backdoor into this meta-algorithm that depends on the individual cars‚Äô position and speed in the
traffic scenario to cause the desired behavior.
Practical Shortcomings. While all these attacks are useful as proofs of concepts, it is unclear how far they would
affect actual autonomous cars. For example, Boloor et al. [8] and Xiao et al. [95] are the only ones considering an action
an attacker could potentially carry out in the real world. More concretely, no attack is evaluated on a real vehicle. A
possible explanation for this could be the cost of an autonomous vehicle, which usually amounts to more than 20,000$.2,
and is probably not affordable for most researchers or their institutions. An additional (unknown) attack limitation is
the time overhead introduced by current attacks. For example, for all four evasion attacks [8, 81, 95, 99], it is unclear
whether the input perturbations could be computed fast enough to harm a car in real-time, or whether (or to what
degree) they would transfer, e.g., can be computed on one model and work on another [63]. None of the attacks tested
with autonomous driving as a case study has exploited an agent within the system. Therefore, to which extent this

5.5
Future Research Directions
The attacks against RL are adaptations of attacks previously proposed against standard ML systems, particularly against
classifiers. In Figure 4, we highlight the connections between the attacks proposed against standard ML systems and
those proposed against ML. The first attacks against RL [47, 56] were proposed in 2017 and were able to make the
system misbehave when a carefully crafted sample was provided as input to the system. These attacks are inspired by
the ones [18, 52] proposed more than ten years before (between 2004 and 2005) against classifiers to have a carefully
crafted sample misclassified. For example, to have a spam email misclassified as legitimate. Also, the first training time
attack against RL was proposed in 2017 [3]. The goal of this attack was to make the system unable to work correctly,
causing a denial of service. In this case, the attack is also inspired by an attack [6] proposed a long time before (2012)
against classifiers. In this case, to make a Support Vector Machine unable to learn to classify samples correctly. In 2018
and 2020, researchers proposed the first poisoning attacks against RL aimed at violating the integrity of the systems. In
particular, in 2018 (2020), they proposed the first targeted [53] (backdoor [40]) poisoning attacks. Both were inspired by
articles proposed in 2017. The first is [42] aimed to have some test samples misclassified by manipulating few training
samples. The second is [29], making the classifier learn to misclassify all the samples containing a trigger. Also, the
18
A Survey on Reinforcement Learning Security
Woodstock ‚Äô18, June 03‚Äì05, 2018, Woodstock, NY
only attack that violates the privacy of RL systems stealing it [24], proposed in 2021, is inspired by an attack previously
(in 2016) proposed against classifiers [89].
However, different attacks proposed against classifiers have not yet been tested against RL. Also leveraging on this
analysis, in the following, we will highlight different interesting future directions in developing attacks against RL.
Privacy Violation. The only attack that compromises the system privacy tested so far against RL is model stealing.
However, other attacks might be potentially adapted to work against RL. One of these attacks is model inversion [24],
in which the attacker tries to reconstruct some training data by observing the model input and the agent behavior. The
other is membership inference [79], where the attacker would like to understand if a given sample was or was not part
of the training dataset.
Availability Violation. All the availability attacks proposed so far against RL manipulate the training samples to alter
the policy. However, another attack called ‚Äúsponge attack‚Äù [80] was proposed against classifiers and can potentially be
adapted to work against RL. With the attack proposed in [80], the attacker does not need to manipulate the training data
to perpetrate this attack. At test time, the attacker provides the system inputs carefully crafted to increase the system‚Äôs
time response, potentially delaying the response of real-time systems to the subsequent inputs. This kind of attack that
slows down the system was also perpetrated at training time by altering the code used to train the algorithm [15].
Autonomous Driving. It is required to either study more black-box attacks or understand more in detail the transfer-
ability [63] of attacks in reinforcement learning. Otherwise, the computation time of the attack should be provided
so that the real-time risk can be assessed. In addition, more realistic attacker actions that are aligned with real cars,
at least from the design perspective, are required. In this context, it is important to evaluate attacks on real cars or
very close models of existing cars encompassing the full system. For example Jia et al. [38] show that only fooling
object detection does not suffice to alter the output of the entire objection detection pipeline within a vehicle. These
real-world evaluations could shed light on whether sequential or non-sequential attacks are more dangerous and
whether black-box access suffices to affect a car‚Äôs security.
6
DEFENSES
Different defenses have been proposed to make RL more robust against attacks. In the following, we first explain how
state-of-the-art defenses against RL can be categorized. Then, we present a taxonomy of the defenses proposed to
secure Single-agent and Multi-agent reinforcement learning systems. Because, as we explained in the introduction,
autonomous driving is of paramount importance, we have also investigated in detail the article that considers this
application. However, to our knowledge, a single defense has proposed a defense considering it. Therefore, we mainly
discuss the open challenges. Finally, we discuss interesting feature directions regarding the development of defenses for
RL).
6.1
Categorizing the Defenses against RL
All the proposed defenses techniques proposed to defend reinforcement learning adapt defense techniques previously
devised for classifiers. They can be subdivided into two categories: the ones that try to counteract past attacks (reactive
defenses) and the ones that act to prevent future attacks (proactive defenses) [7]. The former usually tries to detect
and stop the attack (detection) and/or to remove its effect from a system or input altered by it (sanitization). The latter,
instead, try to make the system more robust and can be further categorized depending on the strategy they use to
achieve this goal as:
19
Woodstock ‚Äô18, June 03‚Äì05, 2018, Woodstock, NY
Demontis, et al.
‚Ä¢ Adversarial training: iteratively retrain the system on the simulated attacks. These defenses are heuristic, with
no formal guarantees on convergence and robustness properties.
‚Ä¢ Game theory: model the problem of making the classifier more robust as a Nash [10] or Stackelberg [50] game
where the agent plays with an adversary, deriving formal conditions for existence and uniqueness of the game
equilibrium, under the assumption that each player knows everything about the opponents and the game. They
are more principled than adversarial training; however, they are more computationally costly.
‚Ä¢ Regularization: make the system more robust, penalizing its sensitivity to inputs‚Äô perturbations.
‚Ä¢ Distillation: is a technique that was originally proposed for model compression [32]. It trains a small network
(called student) to imitate the behavior of a larger network (teacher). This technique, if the two networks have
the same architecture, increases regularization [58]. A variant of distillation called "defensive distillation" was
proposed in [64], but it was shown to be ineffective in [11].
As we have explained when presenting the categorization that we used for attacks, the goal of our taxonomy is to be
helpful to both researchers and practitioners. Thus, we should consider not only the peculiarities of the defenses but
also the ones of the reinforcement learning systems on which they have shown to be effective. Therefore, we categorize
the defenses proposed against RL in terms of the following:
‚Ä¢ Policy Update. The frequency with which the policy is updated (on-policy, off-policy, offline);
‚Ä¢ Defense Technique. The type of defense technique (i.e., adversarial training, detection, etc.);
‚Ä¢ Attacker‚Äôs Capability. That denotes the capabilities the attackers have to have to perpetrate the attack. It is
subdivided in: (1) Attacker‚Äôs Action, which is the action that must be performed by the attacker, and, as we
discussed, could be to monitor the inputs of the RL system or to alter them (2) Poisoning the eventual ability of
the attackers to alter the input during training, which can be true if they have this capability and false otherwise.;
‚Ä¢ Attacker‚Äôs Knowledge. Level of knowledge of the victim system, which may be white-, gray-, and black-box;
‚Ä¢ Attacker‚Äôs goal. The result the attackers would like to obtain with their attack;
‚Ä¢ Sequential Attack. The eventual temporal dependence of the attack on the current or previous state;
‚Ä¢ Attacker‚Äôs Agent. whether and how the attacker uses an agent to carry out the attack.
In the following sections, we present a taxonomy of the defenses that have been proposed against single- and
multi-agent RL algorithms, subdividing them according to the security violation they aim to contrast.

The majority of them focus on attacks that try to minimize the expected reward by manipulating different components
of the RL system, namely, the observations, the environment, or the action chosen by the agent. The defenses proposed
to counter these attacks are mainly based on adversarial training [56, 65, 67, 84, 87, 100, 101], which allows increasing
robustness to the perturbation of a specific component. In [31], the authors propose a defense that, analyzing states
and rewards, can detect and restore the observations altered by the attacker. The work in [101] proposes a regularizer
21
Woodstock ‚Äô18, June 03‚Äì05, 2018, Woodstock, NY
Demontis, et al.
that penalizes the sensitivity of the policy to alterations of the observations. The authors of [21], instead, try to reduce
the sensitivity to the perturbation of the rewards by adding noise to the rewards during training. This defense is
certified; namely, it provides a certificate for the maximum reward change under a bounded perturbation of the reward‚Äôs
observation. In [71], the authors propose using an ensemble of models trained with adversarial training to learn a policy
robust to parametric model errors as well unmodeled effects. However, they test the robustness of the proposed defense
only against random perturbations and not against attackers that craft worst-case perturbations.
A single work has proposed a defense against targeted evasion attacks [45]. The authors propose a mechanism to
counter attacks that alter the action chosen by the agent to force the environment to reach a given target state. This
work analyzes three different strategies to perform adversarial training: (1) jointly training an untrained legitime agent
and an adversarial agent; (2) training an untrained legitime agent that plays against an already trained adversarial agent,
(3) fine-tuning the legitime agent while it plays against a pre-trained adversarial agent. Their experimental analysis
shows that the third strategy is the only one that allows for increasing the robustness of the legitimate agent.
Availability Violation. Only a few works have proposed defenses against availability attacks. The authors of [2]
propose using game theory to reduce the vulnerability against attacks that force the victim to learn a policy chosen by
the attacker altering the reward at training time. The work in [21, 30], instead, proposes defenses against attacks that
try to make the agent unable to accomplish the desired task, minimizing the expected return. In [21], the authors focus
on attacks that manipulate the reward to make the agent select suboptimal actions. To increase robustness against
this attack, they propose to make the agent randomly choose a state from a top quantile of high-reward states. They
claim that, in this way, adversarially placed corrupt states are likely to be avoided. The work in [30], instead, focuses on
attacks that tamper with the states observed by the RL agents and the associate reward so that the trained model learns
to perform sub-optimal actions. The authors consider a system that applies RL for the autonomous cyber defense of a
network under partial observability. They show that if the defender knows the nodes visible to the attacker, the number
of compromised nodes at each step, and the attacker‚Äôs strategy can find and restore the compromised nodes.
Privacy Violation. To the best of our knowledge, no defense has been proposed to protect RL against model stealing,
which is the only privacy-related attack proposed thus far.
6.3
Defenses for Multi-agent RL
Here we provide an overview of the defenses proposed against multi-agent RL. Table 7 provides their compact overview,
and we describe these defenses in more detail below.
The work in [70, 92] provides provable defenses.
Integrity Violation. The majority of the defenses proposed against integrity attacks focus on test-time attacks. All of
them consider attacks that alter some components of the RL system to minimize the expected reward for a given point
in time. Like for single-agents, defenses based on adversarial training [44], detection, [48], and regularization [61] have
been proposed. Another strategy that has been proposed only for multi-agent RL is distillation. The authors of [22]
consider an RL system based on DQN. They modify the system to use two different architectures, which are both trained
online. The original DQN, trained usually, is supported by another DQN, trained on samples perturbed with worst-case
perturbations. The authors use the former to learn the optimal Q-function in a legitimate scenario and the latter to learn
the optimal Q-function in the presence of an adversary. Then they create a DQN that synthesizes the experience of both.
In [70], the authors propose a defense that tries to make the student robust without generating adversarial examples.
22
A Survey on Reinforcement Learning Security
Woodstock ‚Äô18, June 03‚Äì05, 2018, Woodstock, NY
To this end, they use a loss that maximizes the probability that the student chose the same action chosen by the teacher,
minimizes the entropy of the unwanted actions, and penalizes the sensitivity to input perturbation using a regularizer.
To facilitate attacks that violate the system‚Äôs integrity, attackers can also tamper with training data. A single defense
against these attacks has been proposed so far. In [93], the authors focus on attacks that force the victim to learn a
target policy adopted only when a backdoor, learned by the agent at training time, is triggered. The trigger considered
by the authors is a particular action of another agent in the environment. The authors have investigated if fine-tuning
the agent on clean data can reduce the vulnerability to this attack. They have shown that fine-tuning on legitimate data
is only effective in an extremely limited sense, mainly because the trigger action is seldom encountered in legitimate
data. Thus, it does not make the agent unlearn the trigger, and therefore, the attack remains effective. Notably, this is
the only defense that has been proposed so far against an attack that exploits an agent within the environment.
Availability Violation. The only countermeasure against attacks that violate the system‚Äôs availability has been
proposed in [92]. This defense focuses on attacks that alter the reward to minimize the expected return. To counteract
this attack, they propose an unbiased estimator that, given the noisy reward, approximates the true (unperturbed)
reward.
Privacy Violation. To the best of our knowledge, no defense has been proposed so far to protect RL algorithms against
model stealing.
6.4
Defenses for Autonomous Driving
In this subsection, we discuss defenses specifically in relation to autonomous driving. We first summarize existing
efforts that evaluate their techniques considering autonomous driving scenarios and then discuss requirements for
defenses that should be practically applicable to this scenario. We conclude the section by discussing future work.
To the best of our knowledge, only one defense has been evaluated in the context of autonomous driving, more
specifically on a toy navigation task, which is the game theory-based approach by Banihashem et al. [2]. No mitigation,
however, has been tested on a task more similar to autonomous driving or on a real vehicle. One possible reason, in
particular for the latter, could be the cost of an actual vehicle to evaluate such defenses, which easily amounts to more
than 20,000$.3. This cost is not affordable for most laboratories. Albeit using a simulator can, to some degree, solve this
problem, there are other challenges that defenses should face to be applicable in AD, such as:
‚Ä¢ Requiring only hardware that is usually already on board [78]. For example, it is unlikely that an autonomous
vehicle that is purely based on cameras will be equipped with a LiDar sensor only for defense purposes.
‚Ä¢ Be evaluated considering all the autonomous driving system components [78]. There is a possibility that the
defense interacts with other parts of the car, which has to be taken into account during development.
In contrast, some requirements can also be approximated in a simulator without involving an actual car. These include
the introduced overhead, which cannot be too large as otherwise, the car cannot react properly anymore. Some of the
defenses discussed in this section (for example, when based on regularization [21, 48, 92] or distillation [22, 70]) do not
introduce overhead neither at test nor at training time, whereas adversarial training [67, 84, 88] introduces an overhead
only a training time. They are thus more practical in this sense because the training can be done with a simulator.
Also, modifying RL systems by leveraging previously proposed techniques [34] to predict the influence of the other
agents in the environment might increase the security of autonomous driving.

6.5
Future Research Directions
Many defenses have been proposed so far; however, there are still interesting research avenues regarding the defenses
for RL.
Privacy Violation. A recent attack [12] has shown that it is possible to steal a DRL model by observing states and
actions. Namely, to create a copy of it, that: (1) matches or exceeds the accuracy of the original model; (2) has a similar
behavior as the original model (it commits the same errors). This attack can be used to copy a competitor‚Äôs DRL model
or create a surrogate that attackers can use to craft attacks that transfer against their target model [19]. No defense has
been proposed so far against this attack.
Integrity Violation. So far, the only defense proposed against training-time integrity violations is [93], which consists
of fine-tuning the DRL algorithm on a clean dataset. However, the authors showed that this technique is ineffective;
thus, to date, no defense has been shown to be effective against this type of attack for RL. Nevertheless, different
defenses proposed for classifiers could be adapted and applied, including those which examine training [86] or test data
to detect the trigger [93], and those which increase regularization. [16]
Availability Violation. As we have discussed before, the only defense that defends attacks carried out exploiting an
agent within the environment is [93]. No defense has been proposed against attacks that exploit an attack within the
environment to cause an availability violation, for example, the adversarial policy attack [28].
Autonomous Driving. Future work should clearly communicate the hardware requirements of the defense. Further-
more, the mitigation‚Äôs introduced time overhead during both the training and test phase should be stated clearly and in
percent overhead of normal training/operation time or directly an appropriate time unit (e.g., seconds). It also remains
an open question of how to evaluate defenses on the system level, or if a suitable simulator can be built or cars can be
provided for research purposes. Finally, given that cars are highly standardized in terms of safety and security, it might
further be necessary that future defenses ultimately comply with existing or new industrial standards [76].
7
CONCLUDING REMARKS
In this survey, we analyze and categorize state-of-the-art attacks and defenses against RL algorithms. The categorization
that we provide, differently from the ones available in the previously published works, allows system designers to
understand which defense they can apply to defend the system at hand against a precise threat. Given that autonomous
driving is a particularly concerning and valuable application, we have also analyzed the articles considering it more
extensively. Our analysis has shown that the studies about the security of RL-based autonomous driving systems are at
their birth. Further studies are needed to assess the applicability of existing techniques to this application. Finally, we
have identified which attacks that have been previously proposed against machine learning have not been adapted and
applied yet to reinforcement learning and for which attacks no defenses have been proposed so far. This allows system
designers to envision possible threats and researchers to explore interesting future research directions.
